awd_titl_txt: Chemical Signatures for the Discovery of Protein Function
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division supports Drs. Mary Jo Ondrechen and Penny J. Beuning from Northeastern University to develop, implement, and verify a novel method for predicting the biochemical function of proteins.  This project utilizes computational chemistry tools in an innovative chemical-properties-based method to discover the biochemical function of protein structures.  It begins with the premise that local structural features at the active site constitute better predictors of biochemical function than does the overall fold.  First it is shown that sets of structurally similar proteins may be sorted into subgroups according to biochemical function, using the active site residues predicted from computed chemical properties, structurally aligning them, and scoring them according to chemical similarity.  Thus for each functional subgroup, a characteristic chemical signature are defined.  Next, structural genomics proteins are analyzed and annotated, using their calculated chemical signatures and seeking matches with the chemical signatures of the previously characterized proteins, and misannotated structural genomics proteins are identified.  For selected cases of structural genomics proteins that have been determined to be misannotated, or for which biochemical function is newly predicted, the predicted functions are verified experimentally by kinetics assays and binding studies. 

Genome sequencing and structural genomics efforts over the past 15 years have provided a wealth of new information about thousands of proteins.  While genome research holds tremendous promise for major future benefits to society, a key step toward the realization of this potential is the ability to determine the function of the thousands of protein structures whose biochemical functions are currently unknown or uncertain; this project addresses that current challenge.  Greater understanding of protein function has many potential benefits in fields outside of chemistry, including agriculture, biotechnology, medicine, biofuels, and "green" industrial processes.  A better understanding of the local structural, electrostatic, and chemical patterns that govern how proteins work so selectively and efficiently will open the door to novel commercial applications.  Such basic knowledge to drive novel high-tech commercial application is important to the future growth of our regional and national economies.  This project also will develop a knowledge base and tools that will enable other discoveries and applications.  In this project a racially diverse group of both undergraduate and doctoral students are trained in methods of computational chemistry, computational biology, and biochemistry.  Experience in these areas is a vital ingredient for United States competitiveness in the global economy.  Individuals with such knowledge and training are in high demand in both academia and industry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Genome sequencing and structural genomics efforts have led to the discovery of tens of thousands of proteins of unknown or uncertain biochemical function. This new knowledge can potentially lead to countless new technologies of great value to humankind in areas as diverse as renewable energy, therapeutics, and environmental remediation. The next step toward reaping the benefits of these discoveries is to find reliable methods to predict the biochemical function of these proteins – What exactly do these proteins do? This project developed a computational method, based on principles of physical chemistry, to predict the biochemical function of protein structures of unknown function. Predictions of biochemical function of selected Structural Genomics (SG) proteins of unknown function have been tested and verified by direct biochemical assay.

Intellectual Merit: This project developed a new computational method, Graph Representation of Active Sites for Prediction of Function (GRASP-Func), to predict the function of SG proteins of unknown function. Computational chemistry tools, together with graph theory, were used to develop an innovative chemical-properties-based method for the discovery of the biochemical function of protein 3D structures. GRASP-Func assigns function using the computationally identified local site of biochemical activity, rather than the entire three-dimensional structure of the protein. Using computed, atomic-level properties of the protein structure is quite different from current informatics-based approaches to protein function prediction. Better understanding of protein function, specifically accurate function prediction, is an important and timely problem because of the high volume of new data obtained from genomics, datasets that require interpretation. Functional assignments of protein sequences and structures have been made typically using informatics-based approaches which, by their very nature, exploit relationships to previously annotated sequences or structures. For most structural genomics proteins, this type of approach results in uncertain functional assignment at best and, in many cases, incorrect assignment. The present approach is based on computed electrostatic and chemical properties; it represents a significant departure from – but is highly complementary to – the more common informatics-based approaches. GRASP-Func eliminates Cartesian alignment for much faster computation time and for the ability to match local active sites without requiring an overall fold match; this opens the door to large-scale identification of protein function by local structural match. Some of the GRASP-Func predictions for SG proteins have been tested and verified experimentally in the biochemistry laboratory by direct assay.

Broader Impacts: This new method for identification of the biochemical function of protein structures constitutes a critical step toward the translation of genome sequencing and structural genomics information into tangible benefits to society. The ability to derive biochemical functional information from genomics data is an enabling technology for the development of innovative, marketable technologies for applications such as biofuel production, environmental remediation, and the green, enzyme-catalyzed production of commodity chemicals. This technique is also valuable for the identification of pharmaceutical targets. Such basic knowledge to drive novel high-tech commercial application is important to the growth of the regional and national economy. The source code for GRASP-Func, the new method that enables and improves protein function prediction, has been made freely available to the scientific community via the world wide web. A total of 12 graduate students, 10 undergraduates, and one postdoc have been trained in the areas of computational chemistry, computational biology, bioinformatics, and biochemical laboratory techniques during the course of this project. The new methods for protein function prediction have been incorporated into the Molecular Modeling course at Northeastern University in a “research in the classroom” model.


Last Modified: 08/27/2018
Modified by: Mary Jo Ondrechen
